_prev_prog_3.Description: Arctic Cold Storage has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of anhydrous ammonia in an amount in excess of 10,000 lbs., which is contained in our refrigeration system.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Arctic Cold Storage LLC has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Arctic Cold Storage LLC, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Arctic Cold Storage LLC has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                 | Process Chemical               | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Ammonia Refrigeration          Anhydrous Ammonia                14,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet C

alARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



1.2.1 Facility Overview



Arctic Cold Storage, LLC operates a commercial cold storage facility for a variety of fruit and vegetables in Cutler, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:

(6) Cold Storage Rooms

(1) Hallway



1.2.2 Facility Location



Arctic Cold Storage, LLC is located at 12582 Avenue 384, Cutler, CA 93615. The latitude and longitude of the high pressure receiver is 36.487510, -119.291958. The facility is located immediately north of Avenue 384 and 1000 feet east of Tulare County Road 201 in a rural area surrounded primarily by agriculture land.



According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in "an area of minimal flood hazard".



Arctic Cold Storage, LLC is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Arctic Cold Storage, LLC has a 1-2% chance of experiencing "potentially minor-damage" due to ground shaking in 2018.

Process Chemistry



The refrigeration system employed at Arctic Cold Storage, LLC is configured for flooded operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component type in the system is summarized below:



High Pressure Receivers

The purpose of each high pressure receiver is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration system. The high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condenser and supply high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The high pressure receivers are equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system; it is located on High Pressure Receiver 3. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Flooded Accumulators

The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters th

e vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the main suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators in the cold storage rooms is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. The liquid ammonia enters the bottom of the evaporator coil and as the liquid boils into a vapor, it rises through the coil and returns to the connected flood accumulator. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Air-Cooling Evaporator (Direct Expansion)

The purpose of the air-cooling evaporator in the hallway is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporator receives liquid from the high pressure receivers. Each evaporator is equipped with an expansion valve which reduces the pressure and temperature of the liquid as it enters the evaporator. The evaporator contains a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refriger

ant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it exits the evaporator and is returned to the main suction accumulator. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporator contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Main Suction Accumulator

The purpose of the main suction accumulator is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The main suction accumulator receives vapor from the flooded accumulators and separates any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the main suction accumulator drains by gravity into the liquid transfer vessel. The main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumulator contains low pressure vapor ammonia.



Liquid Transfer Vessel

The purpose of the liquid transfer vessel is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration system back to the high pressure receivers. The liquid transfer vessel receives liquid from the main suction accumulator. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer vessel reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessel to become subject to high pressure and allowing the liquid to drain, by gravity, into High Pressure Receiver 3. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessel can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.



Compressors

The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphe

re. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the main suction accumulator and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. Each compressor has an integral oil separator that receives the high pressure vapor and separates residual oil from the ammonia so that the oil can be returned to the compressor. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal conditions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.



Evaporative Condenser

The purpose of the evaporative condenser is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators and compressors to the atmosphere. The evaporative condenser receives high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supplies high pressure liquid to High Pressure Receiver 3. The condenser uses air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. Water is contained in the sump of the condenser, which is then pumped and sprayed over the ammonia coil. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condenser contains high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.



Safety Systems



Ammonia Detection

There are two (2) stand-alone ammonia detectors and one sampling system installed at Arctic Cold Storage, LLC. The detection system is interlocked with the refrigeration system controls as follows:

An ammonia concentration monitor is installed outside the machinery room to display the current concentration inside the room;

If the ammonia concentration exceeds the setpoint, a set of 94 lumen LED strobe and 75 dB audible alarm will be initiated outside the room. In addition, the PLC will notify facility personnel;

The sample system is equipped with an ammonia detector, vacuum pump, and tubing which extends to the rooms where a

ir is sampled. The vacuum pump is used to draw air through the tubing into the detector. On two minute intervals, the system toggles from one sample point to the next. The sample systems provide ammonia detection to all refrigerated areas as summarized below:

- Forklift Maintenance Area Sample System

- Cold Storage Rooms 1-6

- Hallway



If the sample system detects an ammonia concentration exceeding the setpoint, the system will activate a visible and audible alarm and notify plant personnel of the situation through the auto-dialer.

Emergency Control Box



The Emergency Control Box (ECB) is installed on the north wall of the machinery room and contains three (3) valves and one (1) switch.

Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve

Switch #1: System E-stop



If necessary, these valves can be used to achieve the following results:

Valve #1 is used to relieve the pressure of the high side of the system to the relief valve discharge termination point. 

Valve #2 is used to relieve the pressure of the low side of the system to the relief valve discharge termination point.

Valve #3 is used to equalize the pressure from a high pressure receiver to a low pressure accumulator.



Relief Valves

All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:

Each relief valve has a set pressure equal to or less than the known MAWP of the equipment that the relief valve protects;

Each relief valve has a capacity which meets or exceeds the requirement of ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A ?15.3.8;

All relief valves are connected to manifolds which terminate to atmosphere, 15 ft above grade or 7.25 ft above the roof;

Select "POP-EYE™" relief valves (manufactured by Hansen) are installed throughout the system. After a valve lifts, a b

attery operated LED light flashes for 2+ weeks indicating a release occurred and the valve needs to be replaced.



Reciprocating Compressor Safety Devices

Each reciprocating compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each compressor package:

High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.

Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.



High Level Float Switch

The main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high liquid level in the vessel. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors.



Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)

The high pressure receivers are equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system.



Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)

The machinery room is equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch (e-stop) that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside the machinery room. The switch can be activated in an emergency by accessing the ECB.



1.2.4 Process Classification



The ammonia refrigeration system at Arctic Cold Storage, LLC consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Arctic Cold Storage, LLC is treated as a single process.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental rel

ease of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Arctic Cold Storage LLC has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration process at the Arctic Cold Storage LLC facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Arctic Cold Storage LLC has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Arctic Cold Storage LLC's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

Ca

lifornia Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Arctic Cold Storage LLC has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Arctic Cold Storage LLC continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Arctic Cold Storage LLC's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that the Arctic Cold Storage LLC management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Arctic Cold Storage LLC has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWri

ter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Arctic Cold Storage LLC has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Arctic Cold Storage LLC now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Arctic Cold Storage LLC employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Arctic Cold Storage LLC will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
